docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK MANHATTAN: MINOR DAMAGE IN SYNAGOGUE FIRE -- An arson that caused minor damage to a Washington Heights synagogue on Saturday night was apparently not motivated by anti-Semitism, the police said yesterday. The fire was set just before 8 p.m. in a metal trash can outside the K'hal Adath Jeshurun synagogue at 85 Bennett Avenue, and seriously damaged a shed and its contents, including file cabinets, desks, computers and items used in religious services. The synagogue itself received minor damage. The police arrested three people at the scene: Jose Ortega, 18, and Christopher Nunez, 19, both of Washington Heights, and a 15-year-old boy. They were charged with second-degree arson, the police said. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: They have lived long enough for their days to be easy, yet on any given day Angelo Furio, 73, and David Heller, 80, are racing around Brooklyn in an old station wagon, making house calls as highly sought-after handymen. Getting a date with them can take weeks. Still, their clients speak their names with awe and adoration, in part because Mr. Furio and Mr. Heller work for no charge, and only for other old-timers whose bodies have become too frail to let them to do much around the house. So when a light bulb needs changing, a kitchen tile comes loose or the sewing machine acts up, Mr. Furio and Mr. Heller grab their tools and go.
docs.abstract: Article discusses work of Elderplan, social health maintenance organization in which elderly members help each other in varying ways; examples cited; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With a union protest rally scheduled for tomorrow night in front of the Metropolitan Opera, the company that runs the restaurants at the Met has made an unusual offer in an effort to end a bitter two-year labor dispute. The union, Local 100 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union, has been at loggerheads with the company, Restaurant Associates, over what procedures should be used to find out whether a majority of the Met's 95 restaurant workers want to unionize.

headline.main: Met Opera Contractor Makes Offer to Union

docs.abstract: Restaurant Associates, which runs Metropolitan Opera restaurants, makes unusual offer to Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union in hopes of heading off protest; company asks union to agree to secret-ballot election if company promises not to file legal challenges if union wins (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: CHLOE the cat lived a long and mostly good life before dying one February morning. But according to Pamela Gordon, Chloe's owner, what should have been a peaceful ending for a feisty survivor was marred by a series of medical mishaps and an insensitive veterinarian. Ms. Gordon, an art dealer who lives in Greenwich Village, found Chloe abandoned in a Paris train station in 1983. She nursed her back to health and good spirits. Chloe was a relatively healthy 19-year-old until early this year.

headline.main: What Price For a Pet's Life?

docs.abstract: Felicia Lee Coping column on Greenwich Village resident Pamela Gordon, who has failed in effort to file suit for pain and suffering against veterinarian after her 19-year-old cat died; notes New York Assemblyman Patrick Manning has proposed bill that would afix liability of up to $5,000 in non-economic damages if person kills or injures pet through unlawful and intentional reckless or negligent act; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the California millionaire Dennis Tito climbing aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft for a visit to the International Space Station construction site, the age of space tourism begins, overturning old rules abruptly. Although Mr. Tito, who is spending a glacially cool $20 million on his trip, is unlikely to be followed immediately by the 747-sized hordes who are held responsible for the sorry state of airline travel today, the barrier between scientists in space and rubberneckers has been breached. Après Tito, Lord knows. So those of us charged with giving practical advice to travelers about their plans and safety must raise our sights still further. Beyond Transcontinental & Western Air; beyond the jet age, beyond the Concorde: On to the age of the space-travel counselor!
